speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Welcome to Open Minds from Creative Commons. I'm Eric Stoyer.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: 2021 marks the 20th anniversary of Creative Commons, and one of the ways we're celebrating is with this podcast,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: which is a series of conversations with people working on the issues we're involved with and subjects we're excited about.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: On today's episode of the podcast, I talk to Audrey Tong.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Tong is an influential free software programmer, a hacker, and the digital

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: minister of Taiwan. Tong became involved in politics during the Sunflower Student Movement

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: of 2014, which was a series of protests against a trade agreement with China. Tong was instrumental

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: in using open technology to help amplify the voices of demonstrators so that they could better

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: communicate their message. Since then, Tong has worked to manifest a vision for how open technology, open data, and radical transparency

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: can result in positive, productive collaboration between government and the people.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Last year, Taiwan was frequently credited with having one of the world's best responses to COVID-19.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: There were a lot of reasons for their success, but a significant one was due to a digital strategy

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: that included information crowdsourcing and open data projects that kept people informed.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: There's a great Wired article on Tong from last year that goes deep on all of this.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: It's called How Taiwan's Unlikely Digital Minister Hacked the Pandemic.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I'll link to it in the show notes because it's definitely worth a read.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: it's definitely worth a read. Before we get into our interview, I wanted to mention that Tong will be one of the keynote speakers at this year's CC Global Summit, which is Creative Commons' annual

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: event that brings together hundreds of leading activists, technologists, educators, lawyers,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: librarians, and other people for discussion, panels, workshops, and community building.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: You can find out more about the event and register for it online at summit.creativecommons.org.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: For now, I hope you enjoy my conversation with Audrey Tong.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I wanted to start by asking you if you could tell me just a bit about how you got to where you are.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So maybe your path from being a hacker to where you are now.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Well, I'm still a hacker. I'm working with the government,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: not for the government. Back in 2014, I helped occupy the parliament in Taiwan. That was in March

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: 2014, and it was called the Sunflower Movement. And with half a million people on the street and

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: many more online, we demonstrated, as in demo, not as in protest, demonstrated that listening at scale is possible

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and people can actually talk about the trade service deal with Beijing in a way that is very well informed,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that has people online as well as internationally joining, and that produces actionable rough consensus.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Of course, for people who was already in internet standard

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: making communities, this shouldn't be a surprise. We already know how to listen to scale, but it is

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: a surprise to many people working in the public service. So I was then recruited as a reverse

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: mentor at the end of 2014, advising the cabinet on how to listen to scale.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And what's kept you interested in working in public service versus in the private sector?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So my work is firmly in the social sector,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: meaning that anyone's contribution is valued, is everyone's business with everyone's help.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So I see myself primarily connecting to the social sector organizations.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And in the public sector, of course, there are many public servants

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: who are also active participants in the social sector after work.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So in the early days of the Sunflower Movement,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: we found that many people who joined the GovZero or G0V movement

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that looks at all the digital services that ends in.gov.tw

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and make forks, that's to say alternate versions

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: of such digital services ending in.g0v.tw,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: so people can just change a 0 to a 0 in the browser bar

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and get into the shadow governments,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: but always forking with the intention to be merged back.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And we found that many contributors to GovZero

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: are actually public servants. So they're

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: also very interested in horizontal connecting together rather than being trapped in their

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: silos, their hierarchical relationships in their day job. And so I see my work is mostly horizontal,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: making sure that the 12 or so ministries who send secondments to my office, as well as the

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: participatory officer network, the PO network in all the ministries, can connect together and

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: listen better to the citizens. So that's my role. I call it a public servant to public service.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: You know, I'm interested to know when you became involved with the open source

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: software community and how that influenced your

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: life? I was involved even before the term open source. I was quite active in CPEN,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that's the Comprehensive Perl Archive Network, around 95, I think, 96, when I first joined as a

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: co-founder. My first startup is all written in Perl.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: I'm also interested in web standards.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So later on, I would participate, say, in the Atom working group to develop a viable alternative to the RSS.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: I'm also involved in the Creative Commons popularization in Taiwan, doing translation work, as well as maintaining

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: the GitHub-like infrastructure called Open Foundry,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: maintained by our National Academy around the turn

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: of century, I think 2003, 2004, and so on.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So yeah, I think the free, liberal, open source movement

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: really defined the way that my work is possible, right? Because

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: previously, as a junior high school dropout, I would not have access to the latest research,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: if not for the open access movement, for example, archive ARXIV preprint, and I wouldn't have

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: access also to the community that builds a cutting edge computer

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: language together. For example, the Haskell community that I will later join in helping

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: shaping the Haskell standard. And so, yeah, I would not imagine a career outside of the

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: engagement to the free library and open source communities.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Something I've definitely seen, and I'm sure you have also over the last several years,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: is that things like openness and even the phrase open source, but transparency, these

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: have also become almost buzzwords that have lost their meaning to some degree because

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: of the very, very loose ways that different entities apply them.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And this is especially true of companies that want to use them almost for sort of marketing

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: purposes and different governments that want to seem like they're doing the right thing,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: but just really are kind of pandering.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: What are some thoughts that you can share about the requirements

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: that must be in place for something

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: to be truly open or transparent?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: YONGJIN PARKERIUOGUNAWONGSEN First of all,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: I think the buzzword situation is actually not that bad

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: if you compare it to, say, big data or blockchain.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So it's still manageable.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: That's what I would say.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And I would say that transparency and participation are, of course, both important.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: But to me, the most important part is whether it's inclusive,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: meaning that people who are affected by the software,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: whether they have a real say in either remixing, customizing,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: or just changing the course of how the software is developed and how it is interfaced with the society.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So I would say that any open source project that focuses on governance, on getting the most inclusive culture possible, is more sustainable.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And the open source projects that are, as you mentioned, started by companies who are not that interested in the co-governance model with their stakeholders,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: almost by definition, do not get to be remixed or reused and therefore less sustainable. And so I think this is a natural evolution-like process

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that rewards the projects that take care

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: about the stakeholder communications

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and inclusive accountability.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So I think it is a natural progression

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: toward only leaving the project

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that take care of the non-open washing,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: the actual inclusive part,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: to remain. So I'm cautiously optimistic about this dynamic.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I've heard you talk about different social media efforts as either being

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: pro-social or anti-social in their nature. I still get excited about the idea of what social media

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: could be for us, how it could foster dialogue. I mean,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: it does this in some ways and it elevates voices in some ways and it even brings us together in

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: some ways, but in so many other ways. And in practice, it feels like it has the opposite

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: effect of what I thought that social media would feel like, you know, because you've done so much

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: thinking about this. I'm interested to know if you could talk about why you think that this has

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: become the sort of way that social media feels for so many people and whether it's what we're going to be stuck with perpetually or whether there's another way that is possible going forward.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Well, to me, Wikipedia or GitHub are also social media.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: The difference is that the creativity in such pro-social places are directed to the commons,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: whereas in the more anti-social corners of social media, there's no sense of social production or social creation by default.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: By default, it's people standing their ground, sharing their positions, but also attacking at one another, not just contributing alternate

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: positions, but actually making ad hominem attacks and conspiracy theories and things like that,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: because the experience design by default privileges the kind of outrage, the kind of emotion

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that helps, for example, selling advertisements and so on.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So on the Taiwanese equivalent of Reddit, for example, the PTT, it doesn't even have any shareholders.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: It doesn't have any advertisers.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: It's entirely subsidized by the National Taiwan University.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: But because of academic freedom, this student's pet project, which has been running for 25 years, is essentially social sector-run digital public infrastructure.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So people are joining with the norm of contributing to the commons instead of attacking one another.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And the interface does not privilege any of those people who, for example, place targeted sponsor advertisements to incite emotions and things like that.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So I think the platform's incentive is really at play here.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And we need to make the digital equivalent of town halls, of libraries, parks, national parks, and so on, in order to have a careful deliberation about public issues.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Of course, there's still a place for like the nightlife district, right?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: For the more distraction-oriented, serving addictive drinks, private banisters, very loud.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: One has to shout to get heard.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Places, it's just we should not purpose those places to work on public deliberation.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: You know, I think of Wikipedia, I think of GitHub, especially Creative Commons, especially.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: These are somewhat rarefied spaces.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So while they are social media, while they are open in theory to anyone to get involved with, they require in practice a certain kind of vocabulary.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Do you have any thoughts about how to open up those spaces to people that maybe don't

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: have as much sophistication

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: around some of those communities or the thinking that goes into being a part of them?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Mm-hmm. Yeah, I worked briefly in the visual editor team in Wikipedia because many people

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: who contribute to Wikipedia report that the wiki syntax is actually the thing that prevents them from contributing, not because

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: they can't learn the syntax, but because syntax is quite unforgiving in a sense that if you make

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: a typo, then the page looks really bad. And then, of course, people will fix it afterwards. But

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: the initial contributor's experience isn't that great. So I think we need to focus,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: just like the visual editor,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: on the initial experience. And GitHub has been doing a lot of these to simplify the admittedly

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: quite complex algorithm of the Git algorithm and share it in such a way that anyone with a phone,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: anyone with a touchscreen can just treat it as a wiki, right, to click, to edit, to preview,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: to save, and things like that. So I think a collaborative environment in, for example,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Taiwan's administration, we run our own collaboration platform, and it's called

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Sandstorm. It's also open source. And we make sure that people's initial experience is,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: for example, ordering Lunchbox together,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: which is also co-creation.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: It's like Google Form, right?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Google Form is actually the most accessible part

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: of the entire Google Apps collection.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: But we, of course, have a free software alternatives.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And from Forms, then it's spreadsheets,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: which is also quite forgiving. If you type a formula wrong, it only affects that cell and maybe some other individual cells,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: but certainly it doesn't crash and so on.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So gradually, people from forms to collaborative edits,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: simultaneous co-editing documents to spreadsheets and so on,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and eventually they learned that it's actually very easy to start

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: a co-creation project. And meanwhile, there's a Slack-like RocketChat channel in the background

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: that helps to handhold the initial onboarding process for the public service.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Why do you think tools like RocketChat instead of Slack are important?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Why is open source an important part of these systems?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: In a very practical sense, we prefer open source on-premise deployment because of the cybersecurity concerns.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: We want to make sure that we can deploy defense at depth and also work with penetration testers.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: The Taiwan pen test team, such as DEF Core, of course, is internationally quite well known now.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: because we can get the entire data flow, the entire routing, and so on,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So because Taiwan is quite literally at the front line of cybersecurity

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: engagements, we really prefer open source rather than the on-the-cloud software that we don't have

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: good data flow control. You mentioned conspiracy theories, and I'm curious because I know that

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: you've done a lot of thinking around this. I've specifically heard about you using humor.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I think that the line is that you use humor to wash the rumor.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Humor over rumor.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: That's right.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: How does that work?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Because that's something I think a lot of people need some insight into. The basic idea, as I mentioned, many messages that travel out outrage eventually get channeled to conspiracy theory

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
